description: Imaginary portrait of Johannes Scottus (on the right) in Honorius of Autun’s Clavis physicae: Paris, BnF, lat. 6734, fol. 3r. John the Scot engages in a discussion with ‘Abbot Theodorus’ about his theological treatise on the creation of the world, the Periphyseon. Theodorus holds a banner with the text: “he reveals the light of dogma by the sharpness of his mind”, and John Scottus holds a banner saying: “He seeks to make hidden things clarify themselves.”

Different terms are used to introduce the interlinear gloss. These include abbreviations for ‘scilicet’ (‘s’) and ‘id est’ (‘i’), both meaning ‘that is’ and offering explanations of Boethius’ wording.

Here the word ‘exemplum’, ‘example’, has been added above the word ‘dico’, ‘I say’, in the text, indicating that Boethius is about to introduce an example.

f. 11r: ‘Rara est adeo concordia formae atque pudicitiae’: ‘Beauty rarely coincides with chastity’ (Juvenal, Satires, 10.295) – gloss to De inventione I.XXIV.35, where Cicero notes that a person could be either handsome or ugly.

f. 41v: ‘Facilius est commendare paupertatem quam sustinere’: ‘It is easier to praise poverty than to put up with it’. The quotation is attributed to ‘Seneca’ and paraphrases Seneca the Elder’s Controversiae II.18. The passage glosses the question of appropriate reward for virtuous acts (De inventione, II.XXXIX.115)

f. 70r: ‘Nichil est iniquius his qui nusquam putant esse subtilitatem nisi ubi nihil est praeter subtilitatem’: ‘Nothing is more unfair than to think that acuteness is only present when there is nothing present but acuteness’. Quoting again from Seneca the Elder (Controversiae, I.21, trans. Winterbottom, LCL 463, p. 21), the quotation glosses Rhetorica ad Herennium II.XI.16, which concerns the dangers of ambiguous oratory.
Who is Magister Iohannes de P[arvi?] ponte? Was he, like Adamus Parvipontus [link], a master who taught on the petit pont in Paris?
Who is Magister Alexander, referred to here in a gloss to the Rhetorica ad Herennium (f. 61r)?

Ramon Llull was also a frequent user of the library of Sorbonne. In 1311 he donated a copy of his works to the library and requested that it would be chained to the bookcase; a common but not so subtle way of preventing a book from being stolen.

Opening of Cicero’s De inventione in Leiden, UB VLQ 103, f. 1r. This manuscript was part of Richard’s collection (Biblionomia, 27), before being included in Gerard d’Abbeville’s bequest to the Sorbonne.

Richard’s entry for this book reads‘[Cicero’s] first book on rhetoric and his second ad herennium in one volume whose sign is the letter C’, the letter indicating the classification of the manuscript in his collection (Paris, Bibliothèque de Sorbonne, MS 636, f. 9r)

In this ninth-century manuscript of Prosper of Aquitaine’s chronicle, snakes in the margin warn the reader that a heretic is about to enter the narrative. The use of this symbol points to a close association between serpents and heretics.
resource: Brussels, KB 5169, fol. 42r copyright Brussels, Koninklijke Bibliotheek, Special Collections

description: Detail from an illustration from the Hortus deliciarum, the first encyclopedia written by a woman. The author is Herrad of Landsberg, abbess of Hohenberg. ms. Strassbourg, Bibliothèque municipale, ca. 1180. The manuscript was destroyed in a fire in 1870, but several copies of the illustrations were made in the course of the 19th century. This reproduction was made in 1818.

De scorpione “According to Solinus, the scorpion is a serpent with a friendly face like a maiden but has a poisonous sting in Its knotty tail” Thomas of Cantimpré, De natura rerum. Valenciennes, BM. 320, f. 138

West door, Cathedral of Chartres, c. 1150. The throne of wisdom, framed by the liberal arts. The complex iconographical program is believed to have been designed by the scholar Thierry of Chartres, chancellor of the cathedral school from 1141 to c. 1155. Famous twelfth-century scholars such as William of Conches, John of Salisbury and Gilbert of Poitiers studied in Chartres.
Below each art is a famous practictioner. Dialectica is seated above (or supported by) Aristotle
Aristotle is depicted as the architect of thought
Dialectica from close up. the creature she is holding is according to some scholars a serpent, according to others a scorpion
Sculpture of Lady Dialectica next to Lady Grammar. Porch of the Münster of Freiburg in Breisgau, 13th century
Admont, Stiftsbibliothek 128, f. 13v
The attribute of the treacherous serpent has disappeared. It is replaced by rational, step by step argumentation

Cambrai, BM, MS 620 (572), f. 1r (detail). The author, Giovanni di Andrea (c 1270-1348), in his study, surrounded by books in chests, bookcases and on his desk. A special carousel (a wooden wheel on which multiple books could be laid out) allows him to consult multiple books at a time. Depicted in a manuscript from around 1340-1345, made in Bologna.
Paris, BnF, Fr. 12584, f. 61r (detail), manuscript from North-East France, 1300-1350.

Paris, BnF, Lat. 15350, f. 1r (detail): Here is a detail from a manuscript with quodlibetical disputations from, among others, Thomas Aquinas. The structure of the disputation is clear, with three questions (‘tria sunt quesita’, and further division of these into subquestions with ‘utrum’ (‘whether’).
Lyon, BM, MS 128 (060), f. 2r: Rhetorical manual from the 15th century, with Rhetorica ad Herennium and, among others, a ars praedicandi.

alttext: Breviculum ex artibus Raimundi Lulli electum – Karlruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 4r (detail).
description: Breviculum ex artibus Raimundi Lulli electum – Karlruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92, f. 4r (detail). The image shows Ramon Llull sitting on an elevated chair, teaching an attentive crowd. He discusses (in green letters) how to distinguish between right and false arguments and opinions.

alttext: Karlruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92,
description: The army is lead by by Aristotle, riding his horse ‘Ratiocinatio’ (reasoning). Averroes follows, on the horse, ‘Ymaginatio’ (imagination).

alttext: Karlruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92,
description: In the tower of falsehood rhetorical and dialectical sins are found, such as ignorance, confusion, impossibility, emptyness. Truth is held capture in the dungeon.

alttext: Karlruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92,
description: Ramon Lull pulls a chariot with eighteen principles of the art of arguing well: among them are goodness, greatness, wisdom, endurance, etc.

alttext: Karlruhe, Badische Landesbibliothek, St. Peter perg. 92,
description: f. 28v (detail): Note that the circle on the bottom right is designed to become part of an assembled stack of circles, which can then be moved to make different combinations.

alttext: Museo dell’ Opera del Duomo, Florence.
description: Plato and Aristotle in dispute. The relief represents the art of dialectic and is part of a series of the seven liberal arts made by Lucca della Robbia for the belltower of the Duomo in Florence, 15th century. Museo dell’ Opera del Duomo, Florence.

alttext: Fresco by Pellegrino Tibaldi, c. 1588- 1599, Madrid, El Escoria.
description: Zeno of Elea shows youths the door to truth and falsity. Fresco by Pellegrino Tibaldi, c. 1588- 1599, Madrid, El Escoria.

alttext: c. 470 BC Louvre, department of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Antiquities, G384
description: Boxing scene: athletes in guard position. Detail from an Attic cup, c. 470 BC Louvre, department of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Antiquities, G384
Brussels, KB 5169, fol. 42r.
resource: Copyright Brussels, Koninklijke Bibliotheek, Special Collections

alttext: Verona, Bibl. Capitolare CCLI, thirteenth century, f. 10r.
description: The liberal arts are building a cart. Verona, Bibl. Capitolare CCLI, thirteenth century, f. 10r. Illustrated copy of Alanus de Insulis’ Anticlaudianus

Rippol, eleventh century. Provenance: Moissac. A note in the margin says: “The heresy of bishops Elipand of Toledo and Felix bishop of Urgell [….] and erradicated” “heresim elipanti toletane et felicis urgelletane episcopis […] ta et erradicata”
resource: Bibliotheque Nationale de France, photo by Irene van Renswoude

description: Baptism of Christ.  Mosaic in Arian baptistry in Ravenna. The baptistry was built by King Theoderic the Great around 500. The fact that Christ is depicted as a young and beardless man is meant to convey that Christ the Son is inferior to God the Father and not ‘of one substance’ with him.

alttext: Biblioteca del Monasterio de El Escorial, D. I. I., f. 129v
description: Council of Toledo (generic illustration, representing each Visigothic council held in Toledo in the sixth and seventh centuries) Codex Emilianensis, c. 992 Biblioteca del Monasterio de El Escorial, D. I. I., f. 129v
Tʻang dynasty fragmentary silk painting, ninth century. Christian saint, possibly a Nestorian image of Jesus Christ. British museum, asset 1613030451

alttext: mural in the cathedral of La Seu d’Urgell
description: The murals were removed from the cathedral of La Seu d’Urgell between 1927 and 1933 and are now in the Museu Nacional d’Art de Catalunya.
Stiftsbiliothek 516

Heloise, Problemata. Paris, BnF. Lat. 14511, f. 17v and 18r. St. Victor, late 14th, early 15th c. This section of the manuscript was copied for the humanist scholar Simon Plumetot (1371-1443), who collected texts written by Abelard, which perhaps explains the added title at the top of the page. Plumetot donated this and other manuscripts related to Abelard to the abbey of St-Victor, where he had studied.
Paris, BnF. Lat. 14511, f. 44v “Incipit sermo magistri abaelardi ad virgines paraclitenses de studio litterarum”

resource: Bibliotheque Nationale de France, photo by Irene van Renswoude

description: Paris, BnF. Lat. 12949, f.23v

alttext: Paris, BnF. Lat. 12949, f.23 bis r
description: Underlined are: versuS iohanni Scotti, bedae, Virgilii, Prudentii, Persii, epitaphium sancti augustini. “Vivere post obitus vatem vis nosse viator? Quod legis, ecce loquor, vox tua nempe mea est” “Passerby, do you wish to know how poets still live after death? Those words you read, behold I speak. Your voice is very much mine” [Possidius, Vita Augustini, 3.18]
